text: there is no desert more intimidating
than the souffle but the reality is it's
actually pretty easy to make you just
have to know a few tricks and tips and
I'm going to show you that method today
it's really simple play is two
components really a bass and whipped egg
whites now once you know the method you
can really take this and play with it
and flavor it in any way you'd like in a
small pot I have one cup of whole milk
add to that one vanilla bean I like to
cut through the vanilla bean completely
separating it into two halves and then
slide the back of your knife along the
vanilla bean scraping up the seeds that
goes right into the pot here now if you
didn't have vanilla beans you could
certainly use a little bit of vanilla
extract here add a generous pinch of
coarse salt so this just needs to come
to a simmer and really what you're doing
is you're infusing the milk with the
vanilla bean I have three egg yolks here
and these are from large eggs and I have
a quarter of a cup of superfine sugar
which is also known as castor sugar and
I'm going to mix that together with a
quarter of a cup of all-purpose flour I
like to mix the flour and the sugar
together because it prevents clumps from
forming it kind of breaks up the flour a
little bit and you're less likely to get
clumps in your pastry cream so now this
goes right in with the egg yolks here
just whisk this together this mixture is
a little bit thick but once you add that
hot milk it should lighten up nicely now
the flour adds the thickness that you
need for a pastry cream I'm going to
just fish out my vanilla beans because
they've imparted their flavor in the
milk and now for the process which is
called tempering I'm going to gradually
add some of this hot milk into my egg
yolk mixture here so I'll take about
maybe half of it and you want to whisk
this quickly and make sure that it's
nice and smooth
and so now I'm gonna take this tempered
egg yolk mixture and it's gonna go right
back into the pot with the rest of the
milk here so now I need to bring this up
to a boil and cook the pastry cream for
about one to two minutes until it's
really thick and slightly shiny so the
pastry cream here it's ready to go so
here's the fun part what you can do is
you can flavor this base in so many
different ways whether you like a lemon
souffle you can add a quarter of a cup
of lemon juice and two teaspoons of
lemon zest the same thing if you like
tangerine or eat an orange would be
great it gives that kind of creamsicle
flavor to your souffle I really love
passionfruit and you can use a quarter
of a cup of the passion fruit puree and
I'm sure there are a lot of chocolate
lovers out there I'm a chocolate lover
as well this is milk chocolate but you
can use bittersweet chocolate whatever
your preference may be so this is 7
ounces of melted and slightly cooled
milk chocolate and that goes right into
the pot here with your thickened pastry
cream or base and so just stir this
together until it's nice and smooth it
gets a little gluey and thick but really
we're gonna lighten this mixture up once
it's cooled completely with egg whites
which is the other component in the
souffle so this looks well mixed I'm
gonna put it right back into the bowl
that I started with cover this with
plastic wrap and you want to make sure
that you press it directly on the
surface of your base here so that it
doesn't form a skin and now this has to
cool completely so that's gonna take
probably about an hour maybe an hour and
15 minutes or so before we add the egg
whites to it I have five large egg
whites here in my stand mixer I have a
whisk attachment and I'm gonna start off
on low speed and I'm going to break up
the egg whites a little bit always when
you're whipping egg whites you want to
make sure that your bowl is perfectly
clean free of detergent or fat because
that will inhibit the volume or the
whipping of the whites I'm going to add
a pinch of cream of tartar which helps
in stabilizing your egg whites I'm going
to gradually adjust the speed as I'm
whipping the egg whites and
about medium here and what that does is
starting off at a lower speed and
graduating to a higher speed creates
lots of little bubbles instead of a few
bigger bubbles which is really helpful
in creating a stable egg white and you
really need that stability because in
baking with these souffles you want them
to have enough structure so that they
hold their shape so I'm at medium here
we're getting nice and foamy I'm going
to increase it even a little bit higher
to a medium-high speed so the egg whites
are nice and opaque they're very white
and they're just about at soft peaks so
now I'm going to add two tablespoons of
superfine sugar and this is really what
makes whipped egg whites into a meringue
a meringue is egg whites and sugar so
slowly add this so that the sugar has
time to dissolve in the egg whites and
now I'm going to increase the speed to
high and whisk this until you get stiff
peaks
so our meringue is at a stiff peak you
can see it's standing straight up it's
glossy and shiny and now is the time to
fold into our base so to do that what
you need to do is take about a third of
the mixture and this now gets stirred
into the base now you don't have to be
that gentle at this point in time
because really what you're doing is
you're lightening the base up a little
bit more and lightening this mixture
will help in folding in the rest of the
egg whites so now add the rest of the
whites here and here is where you need
to be gentle you want to bring up the
base or the chocolate mixture from the
bottom of the bowl up and over the egg
whites and this is called folding I'm
rotating the bowl as I do that so that
you evenly fold or combine the
ingredients you don't want to over mix
here because you will deflate your
batter and you won't get as high of a
souffle but this looks good and now
we're going to fill our ramekins now I'm
using six six ounce ramekins and I have
them brushed with a little bit of
softened butter and dusted generously
with some superfine sugar and what this
is said to do
is to help this do the sides of the
ramekin now there's a lot of controversy
there whether or not that actually works
but what it does is it helps when you're
eating or serving the souffle it doesn't
stick to the side of the ramekin so make
sure you go through the process of doing
that now I'm using an ice cream scoop
here I like to use those for
apportioning and I'm giving a scoop to
each first so that they're perfectly
even make sure your oven is preheated to
400 degrees with the rack in the lower
third of the oven and they bake for
about 16 to 18 minutes so you want to
time this just right and make sure that
your guests are all sitting down at the
table ready for their souffles so the
souffles are out of the oven they're
risen and set and now moving quickly
move them to a plate now I have a pair
of tongs that I've wrapped with the
towel it's a little trick in getting the
souffle to the plate quickly now you
know the technique you'll be making
soufflés
whichever flavor you like like a French
chef enjoy guys
